[the morning after Robert orders Clare to drop out of the school play; he is now going back to Seattle]
I wish you didn't have to leave so soon.
[She kisses him]
Have a safe trip.
All right. I'll call you later.
[Clare emerges from the house and runs after him]
Dad!... I'm sorry about last night.
Well, just make sure it never happens again, okay?
Bob, you *could* be more gracious.
That's what she could've been, too.
You're right, as always - I quit the play, told the director exactly what you told me. I lost some face in the process, but... well, that's one lucky understudy.
[Her father nods approvingly]
So when are you coming back?
Late tonight - Well, more likely tomorrow... or maybe the next day, if not the day after that.

[smiles]
In other words, you have no idea. That's okay, Dad; I'm used to it.
[They hug]
Well, see you whenever I see you.
Maybe we can go to a movie this Sunday, or something.

[half-joking]
Gosh, I don't know; is that gonna cut into my SAT-prepping time?

[smiles]
That's my girl.

[in the kitchen, shortly after Robert has left for Seattle; Helen is working on her laptop computer]
... So did you two patch things up?
I gave in and did as he said, if that's what you mean.
...Clare, how do I reset the paragraphs on this thing?
You have to click "format."
I knew that.
Mom, my friends are throwing me a belated birthday party tonight...
Clare!
Laura promised, behind my back, that I would come. I can't just not show up, or none of them will ever speak to me again.
No, no - you know how I feel about *deceiving* your father like this.
It's better than all-out defiance, isn't it? I tried passive resistance and that didn't work, so... Can't you talk to him?
Honey, I don't believe that would do any good. You know how he is. I mean, once he makes up his mind about something...
[sighs]
... Look, I know you think he's too strict, but...

You're calling him *strict?* That's like calling the K2 a molehill! All the other kids in my class are being what, and who, they really are... you know, normal teenagers. He makes me feel as if I froze in time at age 10, without even telling me when or where I've gone wrong.
And sometimes you *behave* like you're 10 years old.
Well, I picked the wrong shoulder to cry on, didn't I?
[laughs]
He let me have more fun when I *was* 10 than he lets me have now. I'm the only girl at my school who doesn't go to dances or have dates - the Odd Lady Out, as it were.
There are more important things than dates and dances. It means a lot to your father that you get into a good college.
Other girls my age get into fine colleges. They aren't nearly as wealthy, and they don't live like nuns in the meantime.

[laughs]
Oh, Clare! It's not that bad!
How would you know? Did your parents raise you the same way?

[grins and shakes her head]
... Touché, Clare. Go on, have fun at the party.
Seriously? Thanks a lot, Mom!
Just see to it that you're home by 11 sharp. And pray to High Heaven your father doesn't get back before you do!

[on the phone, at dinner]
... I really can't believe this, Al. When I left, the Canadian said all outstanding issues had been resolved. All of a sudden, they get cold feet?
[He scoffs; Clare comes in]
I know it's a lot of money...
[Clare greets him with a kiss]
... but it's a good deal for everyone! Yeah - you tell McKenzie to call me at home tonight. Right - any time up till midnight. If I can't do this by phone, I'll have to come back tomorrow.
[He rings off and turns to his wife]
... I don't know what happened. When I left, everything was done. Now the whole deal's falling apart. I may have to go back to Seattle in the morning.
[He turns to their daughter]
... Hi, honey. How are you? Anything exciting happen while I was gone?
Clare got an "A" in math - and in the rest of her major subjects.
That's fantastic! See, didn't I say you could do it?

I always get an "A" in everything, don't I? That was your rule - anything below 90% might as well be an "F"... I also got offered the role of "Emily" in OUR TOWN. I didn't even audition; the director just came up to me during lunch and...

[sighs, cutting her off]
I thought we talked about this.

[half-joking]
Or at least *you* did.

[nods, serious]
Bingo.
I just felt so lucky to receive this role. It'd be awkward if I had to...

[cutting her off again]
I thought we all agreed - no extracurricular activities this semester. S.A.T.s are coming up. *That* should be your focus.
Is that what we all agreed on? Or did you agree on it for all of us? Two different things.
Not around here, young lady. Not as far as you're concerned.
Well, YOU haven't needed to explain that *repeatedly* for my classmates. Heck, most of THEM find time for extracurricular stuff - and even jobs. If they can juggle that kind of load, so can I.

[to her husband]
Honey, the play only lasts a couple of weeks.
I'm sure there'll be rehearsals every night - no. Next semester, we'll see; but right now, your top priority should be making a good college.

[deflated]
Meaning you think I don't care about that at all, just because it isn't all I *do* care about!
[She excuses herself from the table and storms out of the dining room]

[his voice dripping sarcasm]
Well... I'm glad I rushed home to be with my family.
[He excuses himself from the table as well. Helen sighs]

[in court, as Eddie testifies]
So, tell me, Mr. Spencer, was this also part of the game?
[Loomis plays the recorder]

[on tape]
Let's hope your daddy listens to you, or you're gonna lose this pretty little finger of yours. You wouldn't want that to happen now, would you?

[on tape, crying]
No, please!

[shouts]
Would you?
NO!
You better do what I say, or else!
NO, PLEASE!
[Loomis stops the recorder as the court goes stunned]
Is this still a game, Mr. Spencer?
[Eddie does not answer]
Would you like to hear it again, Eddie?

[furiously]
Why don't you go to hell!
[the court murmurs until the judge bangs his gavel]
No further questions, You Honor.
